org.orgName: black students at UMD in general, not necessarily in BSU

div.head: BSU outburst jolts fiery Cabinet session

div.p:
Shouting we don’t have time
to argue with you honkies all
night," Black Student Union
members stormed out of last
night’s Student Government
Association meeting during a de-
­ bate on whether to force the
cheerleading squad to accept
black members.
A bill endorsed by the BSU
to put two black cheerleaders
on the squad immediately and
one black male on the unit after

the spring tryouts, was later
passed by Cabinet, 11-2.
BSU member Earl Wynn told
the joint session of Cabinet and
Legislature “we blacks pay our
activity fees and if we don’t
get what we want we’ll draw
our money out of the activity
fund."
Lynn Reichel, junior class leg-­
­ islator, told Wynn he was “out
of order."
Wynn replied “come over to
me and I’ll show you what law
and order is.”

The blacks went into a closed
door meeting for an hour after
Wynn’s outbursts.
Bob McLeod, BSU president,
said the bill was what his group
had asked for, but said he was
“never satisfied.”
The BSU action was one of
several emotional outbursts
during the marathon meeting.
An hour after the group had
convened, Harvey Shulman, Resi-­
­­ dence Halls Association presi­-­
­ dent, asked to adjourn

figure.p:
BLACK STUDENT Union President Bob Mc-­
­ Leod presented the group’s position on the
cheerleading issue at last night's SGA me­-­
­ eting. McLeod was one of several BSU of­-­
­ ficials who walked out of the meeting.
figure.figDesc: [Photograph shows four people, presumably students attending the SGA meeting. Three are seated; one is standing. The student standing is identified as Bob McLeod.]

div.p:
Shulman was upset because an
amendment to the SGA constitu­-­
­ tion to put veto power in the
hands of the SGA president and not
the Cabinet had passed by con­
sent of the Legislature but not
Cabinet.
He said he disliked having
Cabinet’s vote be so meaning­-­
­ less.
The Cabinet recessed to dis­-­
­ cuss the matter, but SGA Pres­-­
­ ident Jerry Fleisher and vice
President Susie Myerberg stay­-­
­ ed in the meeting.

“There are too many important
things to do here now," Miss
Myerberg explained.
While the Cabinet members
hassled outside. Legislature
voted down a proposal that would
have abolished SGA until March
17.
Approval of the measure would
have canceled elections slated
for the end of this month.
The cheerleading debate
dragged on for two hours as
members fought over whether
to accept the BSU proposal or
the cheerleaders' resolution. The
cheerleader’s proposal call­-­
­

ed for one male black and one
female black cheerleader im­-­
­ mediately.
Diana Yingling, spokesman for
the cheering squad, said the
cheerleaders have always chosen
members fairly.
Cheerleader Beth Brown, cry­-­
­ ing as she spoke, added that in
last semester’s tryouts, several
black girls seemed qualified in
practice but they never returned
to try out.
As the debate continued,
Fleischer suddenly rose to tell
the body “I’m sick of SGA sitting
on its ass.”
He shook his fist and said that
If the BSU's demands were not
met, “I have had it.”
Before Fleischer’s remarks,
Miss Yingling said passage of
the bill forcing the squad to
accept black members was a
violation of the 1964 civil rights
act.
She added that the act forbids
segregation, and black tryouts
would be just that.
